fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: A report on the elections in Poland (Suitors circle a Poland in limbo, page 17, September 27) misstated the drop in support suffered by the Democratic Left Alliance government. Their share of the vote fell from 41% in 2001 to 11% on Sunday, a 73% decrease. In her interview with the Guardian, page 24, G2, September 26, Professor Elisabeth Lloyd, having said that her dissertation was on the "structures and confirmations of evolutionary explanation," added: "It's on a level, you know, with the highest level of science today." The "it" there referred to the current state of "evolutionary explanation" not, as might mistakenly be understood, her personal research in the subject. An agency report, Second human cloning failure for controversial fertility expert, posted on our website, September 26, referred to Dr Panos Zavos "from the University of Kentucky". The university has asked us to make it clear that, while Dr Zavos is a former faculty member at the University of Kentucky and served in the College of Agriculture, he does not represent the university, which does not participate in cloning. The picture of Stephen Hawking, pages 10 and 11, G2, September 27, showed him coxing at Oxford (where he took his first degree) not at Cambridge. We misspelt archaeological in a headline and report, page 15, September 27: Getty museum knowingly bought archeological [sic] treasures stolen from Italy, investigation claims. Collins gives the version we used as the second spelling, but that is not Guardian style. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning +44 (0)20 7713 4736 between 11am and 5pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding UK public holidays. Mail: The Readers' Editor, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax: +44 (0)20 7239 9997. Email: reader@theguardian.com The Guardian's editorial code incorporates the editors' code overseen by the Press Complaints Commission: see www.pcc.org.uk
